Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example:
nasi=nu mii-cɨ mura-tɨ 
pear=gen three-clf receive-med three-clf=gen pear 
‘(I) received three pears.’

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example:
kun hon=ba tu-ta this book=acc take-pst 
‘(I) took this book.’

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Comment: Not mentioned. how comitative is expressed

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Comment: there is an inclusive/exclusive interpretation of some modal clitics (intention vs. invitation to do sth)

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Detailed comment:
proximal: ku-/ka-
mesial: u-/ga
distal: a-/aga-

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Comment: different markers are used for human names+elder kins+professions and others

Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
zjuu-taa=ga ik-ju-i father-appr=nom go-ipfv-npst 
‘(My) father and some people will go.’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?

tu-ja:
take-NMLZ

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?

Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?

Are there possessive classifiers?

jumɨ=nu naaja
[daughter.in.law=GEN name=TOP]
‘the name of the daughter-in-law’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
taa-sa=nu tar-an tall-nlz=nom be.su cient-neg.npst 
‘(It) is not tall enough.’
b. an kɨɨ=nu taa-sa
that tree=nom tall-nlz 
‘That tree is tall.’
an kɨɨ=ja taa-sa-joo-i 
that tree=top tall-vlz-pol-npst
‘That tree is tall.’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Example:
daiban+gɨɨ=nu a-tɨ, jinga=nu hasigo kɨɨ-tɨ, nasi=ba ʔtɨɨ ʔtɨɨ mu-tu-n wake
big+tree=nom exist-med man=nom ladder prop-med pear=acc one.clf one.clf pick.up-prog-npst.adn dsc
‘There is a big tree, and a man props a ladder on (the tree), and (he) is picking up pears one by one.’

[Hiro=NOM hedge=ACC cut-SEQ]

hacuko-san=ga wur-tɨ

child=nom sea=loc2 play-ipfv-npst ‘A child plays in the sea.’

Akira=nom character=acc write-prog-npst

Feature: Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?

Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?

Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?

Example:
arəə ɨn ja-ta that.top dog cop-pst

an ʔcjoo sjensjee ja-ta 
that person.top teacher cop-pst ‘That person was a teacher.’

uroo an hon=ba jum-j+agɨr-ɨ=joo 
2sg.nhon.top that book=acc read-se+raise-imp=cnf1

1sg=top characters write-nlz=foc do.pst

‘There is a tree.’

tɨgan=ba jud-ɨ k-on
letter=acc read-med come-neg.npst

arəə ɨn=na ar-an that.top dog=top cop-neg.npst

tɨgan=ba jud-ɨ k-on

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Comment: Nominative case can be used (apart from subject marking) for objects of transitive verbs that express incapability. Apart from that, there are two markers of nominative: one for S higher on the animacy hierarchy and one for lower.
Example:
wan=ga aik-ju-i 
1sg=nom walk-ipfv-npst ‘I will walk.’ (1st person singular human pronoun) 
(47) ɨn=nu aik-ju-i dog=nom walk-ipfv-npst 
‘The dog will walk.’ (animal noun) 
hanas-i+mici ga sij-an-ba=jaa
[talk-INF+way NOM know-NEG-CSL=SOL]
‘(I) don’t know the way to talk (well), so…’

letter=acc read-med come-neg.npst

ju-dɨ, ka-cjɨ, wara-ta 
read-med write-med laugh-pst

book=acc read-neg-med=and play-prog-pst

Can adnominal property word precede the noun?
Example:
daiban+gɨɨ=nu a-tɨ, jinga=nu hasigo kɨɨ-tɨ, nasi=ba ʔtɨɨ ʔtɨɨ mu-tu-n wake
big+tree=nom exist-med man=nom ladder prop-med pear=acc one.clf one.clf pick.up-prog-npst.adn dsc
‘There is a big tree, and a man props a ladder on (the tree), and (he) is picking up pears one by one.’
